Malariae.info: Plasmodium malariae is one of the five species of Plasmodium that commonly infect humans. It causes a disease that has a relatively long incubation period.
Malariae.symptoms: Symptoms include fever, chills, headache, and malaise. The fever typically occurs in 72-hour cycles.
Malariae.treatment: Treatment usually involves antimalarial medications such as chloroquine or artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT).
Malariae.geography: Found primarily in sub-Saharan Africa, but also in parts of South America and Southeast Asia.
Malariae.prevention: Prevention includes the use of insect repellent, bed nets, and antimalarial prophylaxis in high-risk areas.

Ovale.info: Plasmodium ovale is a species of parasitic protozoa that causes tertian malaria in humans. It is the rarest of the four malaria species that affect humans.
Ovale.symptoms: Symptoms include fever, chills, headache, and muscle aches. The fever typically recurs every 48 hours.
Ovale.treatment: Treatment usually involves chloroquine or ACT. Primaquine is used to eliminate dormant liver stages.
Ovale.geography: Most commonly found in West Africa, but also in the Philippines, Indonesia, and Papua New Guinea.
Ovale.prevention: Preventive measures include the use of insect repellents, bed nets, and prophylactic antimalarial drugs.

Vivax.info: Plasmodium vivax is a protozoal parasite and a human pathogen. It is the most frequent and widely distributed cause of recurring malaria.
Vivax.symptoms: Symptoms include fever, chills, sweats, headaches, nausea, and vomiting. The fever typically occurs every 48 hours.
Vivax.treatment: Treatment involves chloroquine or ACT. Primaquine is required to treat the liver stages.
Vivax.geography: Widely distributed in Asia, Latin America, and parts of Africa. It is the most common cause of malaria outside Africa.
Vivax.prevention: Prevention includes the use of insect repellents, bed nets, and antimalarial prophylaxis in endemic regions.

Falciparum.info: Plasmodium falciparum is a unicellular protozoan parasite of humans, and the deadliest species of Plasmodium that causes malaria in humans.
Falciparum.symptoms: Symptoms include high fever, chills, sweats, headaches, vomiting, and severe anemia. It can lead to complications such as cerebral malaria.
Falciparum.treatment: Treatment involves ACT or intravenous artesunate for severe cases. Prompt treatment is crucial.
Falciparum.geography: Predominantly found in sub-Saharan Africa, but also in Southeast Asia, South America, and the Eastern Mediterranean.
Falciparum.prevention: Prevention measures include the use of insect repellent, bed nets, indoor residual spraying, and antimalarial prophylaxis.
